objects.title: Breaking local stories with economic data (Sponsored by Donald W. Reynolds National Center for Business Journalism)
objects.speaker: Paul Overberg, Jeannine Aversa, Thomas Dail

objects.description: Registration will be located on the 2nd floor of the Hyatt Regency Louisville.
objects.title: CAR Conference Registration (Wednesday)
objects.speaker: TBA

objects.description: Stop by the IRE sales table and take a look at our merchandise. We will be selling books, including the newest title in the IRE beat book series. The large selection of titles we carry will certainly include your interests. The winners of the IRE T-shirt contest will be displayed and on sale. The sales table is also the place to get your ticket to "A Night on the Town" an event that is sure to be a fun time! All proceeds from your purchase help support IRE and its mission.
objects.title: CAR Conference Sales (Thursday)
objects.speaker: TBA

objects.description: Registration will be located on the 2nd floor of the Hyatt Regency Louisville.
objects.title: CAR Conference Registration (Thursday)
objects.speaker: TBA

objects.description: Welcome to the conference! IRE staff will highlight key sessions and events that you won't want to miss while in Louisville. We'll also give you a brief rundown on some of the resources IRE has to offer.
objects.title: Making the best use of the conference
objects.speaker: Jaimi Dowdell, Mark Horvit, Megan Luther

objects.description: This mini-boot camp will walk you through the process of taking a dataset from raw data and turning it into a searchable online database using the Python language and the Django Web framework.  Only 18 seats are available and there is an additional $70 registration fee.  Pre-registrations are accepted on a first-come, first-served basis.  Prospective attendees must register and fill out an application for this hands-on camp.  Please
objects.title: Build your first News App with Django (Friday)
objects.speaker: TBA

objects.description: An introduction to Federal Reserve Economic Data (FRED), the Federal Reserve Bank of St. Louis' signature economics database, with easy directions for journalists to tap into it to add context to their stories related to the economy. FRED contains more than 60,000 frequently updated sets of data, ranging from consumer price indexes to regional (metropolitan statistical area) housing charts and unemployment rates. It allows users to automatically compare the data over varying periods of time in customizable charts, and then easily incorporate those charts into print or web publications.
objects.title: My friend FRED: Using Fed data tools to add context to stories
objects.speaker: Keith Taylor

objects.description: Learn how to create beautiful, interactive data visualizations on short deadlines.  No programming required.  You'll learn everything you need to build data visualizations and publish them to your website just like a video.  We'll teach you how to:
objects.title: Tableau Public for beginners (Hosted by Tableau Public)
objects.speaker: Daniel Hom, Mike Klaczynski

objects.description: Are you new to data journalism or does this happen to be your first time at a CAR conference? If so, this session will help you get on track to make sure that you get the best experience possible from the 2013 CAR Conference. We'll highlight sessions and give you tips for success during and after the conference.
objects.title: Getting started: Digging deep with data journalism
objects.speaker: Angela Caputo, Jaimi Dowdell, Jill Riepenhoff

objects.title: Information design and crossing the digital divide
objects.speaker: Christopher Canipe, Helene Sears

objects.title: Exploratory data analysis
objects.speaker: Chase Davis

objects.description: This day-long, hands-on class taught by Hadley Wickham, author of theggplot2 R plug-in, Assistant Professor of Statistics at Rice University, and developer at RStudio.
objects.title: NewsCamp:: Data Science Master Class
objects.speaker: Hadley Wickham

objects.description: This mini-bootcamp introduces Python as a general purpose tool for data wrangling and analysis.  The daylong class will introduce language basics and useful libraries in the course of a typical data project: sraping data from the Web, inserting it in a database and analyzing the results. Attendees are expected to have a familiarity with databases and SQL.  This class will take place all day Thursday.  There is limited seating and an additional fee to attend.
objects.title: Python mini-bootcamp
objects.speaker: TBA

objects.description: This session will cover prepping and importing data, creating a searchable database, report interfaces and layouts and common customizations.
objects.title: Hands-on: Rapid data publishing with Caspio (Hosted by Caspio)
objects.speaker: TBA

objects.description: FOIA Machine aids journalists and citizens in accessing important government documents around the world that are covered by freedom of information laws. Speakers will demonstrate how journalists can use the platform in regular work and make the FOIA process more successful and organized.
objects.title: Use FOIA Machine to prepare, send and track your public records requests
objects.speaker: Chase Davis, Coulter Jones, Djordje Padejski, Shane Shifflett

objects.description: **Moderated by Wendell Cochran, Investigative Reporting Workshop
objects.title: Waste investigations for any community
objects.speaker: Tim Eberly, Erin Jordan, Josh Sweigart, Wendell Cochran

objects.title: Visualizing networks and connections
objects.speaker: Kevin Connor, Irene Liu

objects.description: *Moderated by Brant Houston, University of Illinois
objects.title: The data-driven story (Part 1) Conceiving and launching
objects.speaker: David Donald, Jennifer LaFleur, Brant Houston

objects.description: Journalists use DocumentCloud to turn documents into data, but did you know you can interact with your documents through DocumentCloud's API? We'll show you how other journalists use DocumentCloud's API and demonstrate how you too can update or access your documents' data with some rudimentary scripting.
objects.title: Down and dirty with the DocumentCloud API
objects.speaker: Ted Han

objects.title: Web tools for investigators
objects.speaker: Mark Horvit, Jaimi Dowdell

objects.description: Caspio's new Map Mashup Wizard (v7) automates Google map intergration in a single wizard and now includes icons and interactive filtering.  Topics covered:
objects.title: Demo: New Map Mashup Wizard (Hosted by Caspio)
objects.speaker: TBA

objects.description: **Moderated by Reg Chua, Reuters
objects.title: Monetizing your work
objects.speaker: Kevin Davis, Tommy Kaas, Nils Mulvad, Reginald Chua, Burt Herman

objects.description: Get an exclusive preview of the new features and redesigned user interface. Plus, learn how to join the private beta for advanced access.
objects.title: Demo: Sneak peek of Caspio Bridge 8.0 Beta (Hosted by Caspio)
objects.speaker: TBA

objects.title: Dig deeper with social tools (Sponsored by Kiplinger Program in Public Affairs Journalism/Ohio State University)
objects.speaker: Mandy Jenkins, Doug Haddix

objects.description: Mobile and responsive web design are changing the way stories are told. Complicated data visualizations, which used to be planned for the desktop, now need to be planned so they can work for mobile, tablets, and desktops. Different devices mean different user-experiences for visualizations, which changes how information is consumed. We'll show some samples of successful and not-so successful data visualizations on a responsively-designed news site. We'll talk about workflow, best practices and user-interface patterns that set you up for success.
objects.title: Mobile + DataViz: Friends or frenemies?
objects.speaker: Miranda Mulligan, Pete Karl II

objects.description: Take your data visualization skills to the next level.  In this class we'll push Tableau's capabilities further to create more complex visualizations.  You'll learn how to:
objects.title: Tableau Public for Pros (Hosted by Tableau Public)
objects.speaker: Mike Klaczynski, Daniel Hom

objects.description: This session will cover data submissions and photo uploads, Geo/mobile tagging for maps, content approval policies and tips to driving traffic and engagement.
objects.title: Hands-on: Build apps with user generated data (Hosted by Caspio)
objects.speaker: TBA

objects.description: This talk will cover how to use Excel Interactive View and Excel embedding to make your articles shine, keep people engaged with your site, with minimal effort and for free. The talk will also be showing off some of the latest features of Excel 2013 that make data analysis a snap.
objects.title: Bringing Excel to the Web with Excel 2013 and SkyDrive
objects.speaker: Cathy Harley

objects.description: These three sessions will show how to take a data driven story from start to finish and includes long-time practitioners as speakers. Using a specific U.S. federal database the team of journalists will cover how to check a database for its flaws and omissions, analyze it and find stories out of it, add reporting and precision editing for the stories, and work to visualize the information and data not only for presentation, but also to elicit more tips and ideas from the public.
objects.title: The data-driven story (Part 2) Putting the package together
objects.speaker: Maud Beelman, Brant Houston

objects.title: Leveling up (with) your community
objects.speaker: Burt Herman, Daniel Sinker

objects.title: Practical machine learning: Tips, tricks and real-world examples for using machine learning in the newsroom
objects.speaker: Jeff Larson, Chase Davis

objects.description: Review methods for importing web data into the Google Docs platform. Learn to fetch external web data, create scripts to schedule fetches in batches and process the data. No programming skills required. Those familiar with the Microsoft Excel application will be familiar with many of the concepts. Experienced programmers can learn to develop web application proofs of concept, prototyping and fetching through API.
objects.title: Wrangling Web data with Google docs - beginner course
objects.speaker: Acton Gorton, Sean Sposito

objects.description: *Moderated by Brant Houston, University of Illinois
objects.title: The data-driven story (Part 3) Bulletproofing and presentation
objects.speaker: Anthony DeBarros, Brant Houston, Cheryl Phillips

objects.description: Format: 3-hr workshop plus optional dinner gathering. Drinks and dessert will be provided during workshop.
objects.title: Hone your Fusion Tables training skills
objects.speaker: Sree Balakrishnan

objects.title: No complaints: Navigating the New American Fact Finder; improvements and updates
objects.speaker: Erran Persley

objects.title: How government is winning the war about releasing data
objects.speaker: Gail Gove, Maurice Tamman, Sarah Cohen, David Herzog

objects.description: Get an exclusive preview of the new features and redesigned user interface. Plus, learn how to join the private beta for advanced access.
objects.title: Demo: Sneak peek of Caspio Bridge 8.0 Beta  (Hosted by Caspio)
objects.speaker: TBA

objects.description: Join your fellow CAR colleagues Thursday at Sports and Social Club for a night of competitive bowling and see which team wins the night's best score.  Beginning at 6:30 p.m., you can grab a drink and socialize or form a team and bowl.
objects.title: A Night on the Town (Social Event)
objects.place: See printed schedule for room information
objects.speaker: TBA

objects.description: Coffee and pastries will be served.  This is an invitation-only event.
objects.title: Networking breakfast for CAR mentoring program participants (Sponsored by Scripps Howard Foundation)
objects.speaker: TBA

objects.description: Registration will be located on the 2nd floor of the Hyatt Regency Louisville.
objects.title: CAR Conference Registration (Friday)
objects.speaker: TBA

objects.description: Stop by the IRE sales table and take a look at our merchandise. We will be selling books, including the newest title in the IRE beat book series. The large selection of titles we carry will certainly include your interests. The winners of the IRE T-shirt contest will be displayed and on sale. The sales table is also the place to get your ticket to "A Night on the Town" an event that is sure to be a fun time! All proceeds from your purchase help support IRE and its mission.
objects.title: CAR Conference Sales (Friday)
objects.speaker: TBA

objects.description: What were the big stories of the year? What were the most creative uses of data analysis? See what your colleagues have been up to and pick up some story ideas at the same time.
objects.title: Year in CAR
objects.speaker: Mark Horvit, Megan Luther

objects.title: Intro to SQLite
objects.speaker: Troy Thibodeaux

objects.title: Mapping 1: Displaying data geographically
objects.speaker: Jennifer LaFleur, David Herzog

objects.description: So much data comes to us in .pdf form or, worse, on paper that we then need to scan. We'll offer tips, tricks and best practices to quickly crack open those dastardly files and get the data in a usable format. We'll look at some of classic methods of breaking down PDFs and we'll introduce a tool that uses XML to splice PDFs and turn them into CSVs.
objects.title: Those dastardly PDFs
objects.speaker: Charles Duncan Pardo, Jim Miller

objects.title: Bringing local Geodata to journalism: Exploring Floating Sheep and the DOLLY (Data on Local Life and You) Project
objects.speaker: Ate Poorthuis, Matt Zook

objects.title: Legal issues, access and big data
objects.speaker: Jon Fleischaker, David B. Smallman, Esq., Sarah Cohen

objects.title: Integrity checks and simple data cleaning
objects.speaker: Joseph Kokenge

objects.description: Performing simple calculations and sorting.
objects.title: Excel 1
objects.speaker: Linda Johnson

objects.description: *Pre-registered attendees only
objects.title: Build your first News App with Django (Saturday)
objects.speaker: TBA

objects.title: NewsCamp::Data science for the perplexed. For everyone
objects.speaker: Hadley Wickham

objects.title: Data viz on a shoestring
objects.speaker: Sharon Machlis, Kevin Hirten

objects.title: Intro to programing in Ruby
objects.speaker: Al Shaw

objects.title: Mapping 2: Importing and selecting data by attribute
objects.speaker: Jennifer LaFleur, David Herzog

objects.title: Introduction to text editors
objects.speaker: Liz Lucas, Jon McClure

objects.description: We'll introduce our project to create the first comprehensive, standardized set of federal election data. This will include a demo of how to access data from the project, and how potential contributors can get involved.
objects.title: The OpenElections Project: Certified election results. For everyone.
objects.speaker: Serdar Tumgoren, Derek Willis

objects.description: Uncover the gold mine of inspection data. Get ideas and techniques on how to track inspectors at each level of government. Walk away with story ideas to impress your boss at home.
objects.title: Inspect this
objects.speaker: Megan Luther, Janet Roberts

objects.description: Calculating ratios and rates.
objects.title: Excel 2
objects.speaker: Denise Malan

objects.title: Data cleaning with text editors
objects.speaker: Liz Lucas, Jon McClure

objects.title: Covert reporting using technology to cover your tracks
objects.speaker: Paula Lavigne, Mike Tigas

objects.title: Mapping 3: Geocoding to merge databases with addresses into maps
objects.speaker: Jennifer LaFleur, David Herzog

objects.description: You don't have to be a dedicated data-hacker to do CAR stories. Stop by to learn tips and tricks to find and turn around CAR stories while working your beat.
objects.title: CAR on the beat
objects.speaker: Ron Nixon, Daniel Catchpole

objects.description: Death to tediously hand-crafted flat files! This killer combo offers a way to suck structured data out of Google Spreadsheets and plug it into whatever program/platform/framework you'd like, via simple javascript syntax. Ergo, the data is easily shared with every reporter, editor, fact-checker, copy editor, etc. in your newsroom, and all updates are real time.
objects.title: Smarter interactive Web projects with Google Spreadsheets and Tabletop.js
objects.speaker: Tasneem Raja

objects.description: Get up and get down with our panel to go home with a game plan to find out if your local public safety departments are arriving. We'll break down all the jargon and provide a shake-and-bake recipe for analyzing 911 response times at any American fire department or EMS shop.
objects.title: Is 911 a joke in your town?
objects.speaker: Ben Poston, Ben Welsh

objects.description: Learn pivot tables, filtering and more.
objects.title: Excel 3
objects.speaker: Coulter Jones

objects.title: Intro to Javascript the right way
objects.speaker: Jeff Larson, Al Shaw

objects.description: Here's your chance for informal Q&A about legal issues. Bring your "hypotheticals" and your own lunch.  Beverages and dessert will be provided.
objects.title: Media Lawyers Brown Bag
objects.speaker: David B. Smallman, Esq., Jon Fleischaker, Monica Dias

objects.description: When it comes to visualizing data, you know you want to be nimble in something. But what should that something be? A look - with examples - at some of the trade-offs between using a tool like Tableau versus a programming approach like D3.
objects.title: D3? R? Tableau? What's right for you?
objects.speaker: Robert Kosara, Amanda Cox

objects.description: Esri experts offer a 50-minute workshop to provide insight into how the company's new ArcGIS Online product can be maximized as a platform to enhance storytelling. Esri Story Maps and other app development tools that require no programming expertise are now available to make digital and print map generation more effective and easier to create.
objects.title: Mapping as a storytelling platform: Esri Story Maps and ArcGIS Online
objects.speaker: Clem Henriksen

objects.title: Data on the fly: Real-time news coverage
objects.speaker: John Keefe, Mark Wert

objects.title: Twitter mechanics, strategy and apps
objects.speaker: Doug Haddix

objects.description: Kickstart your data skills with IRE's mini boot camp.  This series of hands-on classes will introduce you to spreadsheets and databases with IRE's proven techniques.  IRE's current and past trainers will walk you through sorting, calculating and interviewing data.  You'll come away with a solid base for using data analysis in your own newsroom.  In addition, we'll provide you with our boot camp materials to help keep you on track long after you leave the conference.  Only 36 seats are available and there is an additional $50 registration fee.  Pre-registrations are accepted on a first-come, first-served basis.  Registration can be done online when you register for the conference.  Sessions will be held Friday and Saturday afternoon and Sunday morning.
objects.title: Mini-Boot Camp (Friday) Team A
objects.speaker: TBA

objects.title: Excel magic: Advanced functions for data cleaning and more
objects.speaker: MaryJo Webster

objects.description: *Pre-registered attendees only
objects.title: Mini-Boot Camp (Friday) Team B
objects.speaker: TBA

objects.title: Beyond the scoreboard: Using data to investigate sports
objects.speaker: Jack Gillum, Paula Lavigne

objects.title: Getting started with open-source database manager MySQL
objects.speaker: Alex Richards

objects.description: *Moderated by Troy Thibodeaux, The Associated Press
objects.title: From CAR to news apps and back again
objects.speaker: Sarah Cohen, Lena Groeger, Ted Mellnik, Charles Ornstein, Serdar Tumgoren, Derek Willis, Troy Thibodeaux

objects.title: Using OpenRefine to clean and explore dirty data
objects.speaker: Tom Meagher

objects.title: How to serve mad traffic
objects.speaker: Jeremy Bowers, Jacqui Maher, Scott Klein

objects.title: Searching the global deep web for better data and information
objects.speaker: Scott Swigart

objects.description: Tame that stack of documents! In this workshop we'll walk you through the analysis of a large set of text documents (thousands of pages) using two free tools: DocumentCloud and Overview. You'll learn how to upload, OCR, search, visualize, cluster, tag, annotate, and publish your documents.
objects.title: Practical document mining with DocumentCloud and overview
objects.speaker: Ted Han, Jonathan Stray

objects.description: Cloud servers are an amazingly flexible way to use computing resources. Servers and test benches used to take weeks to order and configure, but thanks to the cloud, you can build up arbitrarily complex farms of computers to do your bidding in a few minutes, from serving a dynamic news app to crunching through a data set to trying out a new technology on the cheap. This course will help you understand the thicket of acronyms and programs that make up Amazon's AWS system and will get you started building servers.
objects.title: Amazon cloud basics
objects.speaker: Scott Klein

objects.title: Disasters: Preparing for and digging in after the storm
objects.speaker: Ryan McNeill, Ben Poston

objects.description: Identifying people who appear in two databases can give an investigation sweep and take it to the next level: think about matching camp operators and sex offenders, or felons and almost anything. But such joins are difficult and time-consuming, particularly if you have names but not dates of birth. Learn techniques to sidestep those issues by combining your favorite database software with simple scripting and some old-fashioned reporting. By the end of the session, you'll know how to match messy addresses and how to highlight promising hits based on name alone -- exactly what you need to find some bad guys and beef-up your next project.
objects.title: Finding the bad guys: Tricks for joining lists of people
objects.speaker: Adam Playford, Michael LaForgia

objects.title: Computer Science 101: How to speak the language of the people who speak computer
objects.speaker: Brian Hamman, Anna Boiko-Weyrauch

objects.title: Lightning Talks
objects.speaker: Derek Willis

objects.title: Stats in Excel
objects.speaker: Krista Kjellman Schmidt

objects.description: Join fellow CAR attendees for the presentation of the Philip Meyer Journalism Awards at a reception Friday night with light hor d' oeuvres and a cash bar beginning at 5:15 p.m. in Regency North.  Thanks to
objects.title: Philip Meyer Award Reception (co-sponsored by Northwestern University Knight Lab)
objects.speaker: TBA

objects.description: Please join IRE staff over a cup of coffee to discuss what attracted you to the conference and what you'd like to see in future years.
objects.title: CAR Focus Group
objects.speaker: Mark Horvit

objects.description: Registration will be located on the 2nd floor of the Hyatt Regency Louisville.
objects.title: CAR Conference Registration (Saturday)
objects.speaker: TBA

objects.description: Stop by the IRE sales table and take a look at our merchandise. We will be selling books, including the newest title in the IRE beat book series. The large selection of titles we carry will certainly include your interests. The winners of the IRE T-shirt contest will be displayed and on sale. The sales table is also the place to get your ticket to "A Night on the Town" an event that is sure to be a fun time! All proceeds from your purchase help support IRE and its mission.
objects.title: CAR Conference Sales (Saturday)
objects.speaker: TBA

objects.description: Income inequality zoomed into the headlines with the Occupy movement and the 2012 presidential campaign, but most coverage was more about heat than light. Talk of an "income gap" "or the 99%" obscures a complicated reality and ignores most of the story - trends in the middle class. Income inequality is growing in many places, shrinking in others. Its pace and texture vary. Some causes are global and national, some are local. Come learn better ways to cover a complex story, including how journalists did recent stories and data tools you can use to analyze local trends.
objects.title: The great divide: Investigating income inequality
objects.speaker: Paul Overberg, Himanshu Ojha, Robert Gebeloff

objects.description: Steve Myers will use examples from Hurricane Sandy and other news events to show you how to find photos and information on social media and evaluate their authenticity.
objects.title: Discovery, validation, publication: How to be ready for your social media Sandy
objects.speaker: Steve Myers

objects.description: Navigate SPSS using descriptive statistics and frequencies. Create basic counts and percentages to help you understand your data. Do crosstabs and statistical tests to show the data in different ways.
objects.title: SPSS 1: Introduction to SPSS
objects.speaker: Ken McCall

objects.description: An introduction to Microsoft Access using SQL.  Learn to interview your data by selecting, sorting and filtering.
objects.title: Access 1
objects.speaker: Peter Aldhous

objects.title: Building data-driven beats
objects.speaker: Chris Amico, Matthew Waite, Reginald Chua

objects.title: Fundamentals of programming in Python
objects.speaker: Serdar Tumgoren

objects.description: *Moderated by Rich Gordon, Medill School of Journalism, Northwestern University
objects.title: How can we get the widest impact out of technology projects?
objects.speaker: Larry Birnbaum, Rich Gordon, Ted Han

objects.description: Dispatch is a unique publishing tool that allows journalists working in conflict areas to publish their work and communicate with sources instantly and securely. Using a unique, identity-based encryption scheme, Dispatch helps separate your published work from your real identity, while still giving your readers confidence that the material you post really came from you. And, while it publishes to the internet, Dispatch helps make sure your work gets out even when the internet is down, through direct, device-to-device sharing that publishes to the web as soon as connectivity is restored.
objects.title: Dispatch: Secure, authenticated, instant mobile publishing
objects.speaker: Kanak Biscuitwala, Susan McGregor, Mathias Lecuyer, Madeline Ross

objects.title: SPSS 2: Basic linear regression
objects.speaker: David Donald

objects.description: **Moderated by Megan Luther, IRE/NICAR
objects.title: The one-query story: Quick hits for your newsroom
objects.speaker: Megan Luther, Kate Martin, Grant Smith

objects.title: Fundamentals of programming in Python (cont'd)
objects.speaker: Serdar Tumgoren

objects.description: An overview of summarizing databases with counting and summing using SQL in Microsoft Access.
objects.title: Access 2
objects.speaker: Liz Lucas

objects.title: Beyond mapping: Data analysis using Fusion Tables
objects.speaker: Daniel Lathrop, Matt Stiles

objects.title: Prying it loose: Data negotiation and acquisition
objects.speaker: Roby Alampay, Andy Lehren

objects.description: This panel will identify areas for data journalism exploration by examining the current state-of-the-art baseball data analysis. Sports are the original form of data journalism -- box scores predate open government movements by about a century. And Joseph Adler's "Baseball Hacks" trained newbie Web CAR reporters how to scrape and analyze data sets using Perl and MySQL. Finally, sports analytics are a leading indicator for other kinds of analysis. Sensors, economic analysis, leverage are all de rigeur in baseball but still up-and-coming in data journalism. We'll take the concepts being used to analyze baseball, football, soccer and apply them to standard data journalism chores. A good example of this is leverage -- in baseball, an analyst attempts to find those situations in which a player had the greatest opportunity to change the outcome of a game. In data journalism, we might use a similar tool to analyze critical paths to an election win for a candidate or put together a network graph for bundled contributions to PACs.
objects.title: Inside baseball: What data journalism can learn from sports
objects.speaker: Ryan Pitts, Matthew Waite, Jeremy Bowers

objects.description: Learn how to join tables, matching information from one file to another, using SQL in Microsoft Access.
objects.title: Access 3
objects.speaker: Aaron Kessler

objects.title: Data tactics for the well-rounded business reporter
objects.speaker: Wendell Cochran, Edmund Tadros

objects.title: Scraping with Node.js
objects.speaker: Al Shaw

objects.title: Developing reusable visualization components using D3 and Backbone
objects.speaker: Alastair Dant

objects.title: Getting data into Excel
objects.speaker: Liz Lucas

objects.description: There's a lot to think about when it comes to news apps, but not all of it is coding. What story is it telling? Does it tell it consistently and in a fact-based way? Does the story it tells agree with the reporting (and if not who's got explaining to do!) What's the lede, what's the nut (yes, apps have those).
objects.title: How to edit a news app
objects.speaker: Scott Klein, Aron Pilhofer

objects.description: Linear regression helps you find relationships between two or more variables, but when an outcome has only two possibilities, you need a different tool. That, my friends, is where logistic regression comes in.
objects.title: SPSS 3: Using logistic regression
objects.speaker: Jennifer LaFleur

objects.description: For newsrooms that need to cope with regularly-updated data, the ability to provide both real-time access and custom views to pinpoint newsworthy events is crucial. This panel will discuss some of the considerations when building and maintaining data dashboards, and show some examples of dashboards in action.
objects.title: Dashboards for reporting
objects.speaker: Aaron Bycoffe, Jacob Harris, Derek Willis

objects.description: Helium Scraper is a reasonably low-cost ($140) solution for a lot of scraping chores, even if it’s not the magic bullet. This demonstration will show you when it might work for your project and give examples of how it works.
objects.title: Painless scraping with Helium Scraper
objects.speaker: Sarah Cohen

objects.title: Maps and charts in R: real newsroom examples
objects.speaker: Amanda Cox

objects.description: *Pre-registered attendees only.
objects.title: Mini-Boot Camp (Saturday) Team A
objects.speaker: TBA

objects.description: *Pre-registered attendees only
objects.title: Mini-Boot Camp (Saturday) Team B
objects.speaker: TBA

objects.description: This three-part class is designed for data journalists who are comfortable with the basic tools of our craft but intimidated by the "p-word" and think Aron Pilhofer has signed a pact with the devil. We will cover the basics and show you how a little programming can save you hours or days of time and make you look like a genius to your boss. Requirements: a laptop, a Google sign-in and curiosity.
objects.title: Python programming for the rest of us 1: Google Fusion Tables - the gateway drug
objects.speaker: Ronald Campbell, Christopher Schnaars

objects.description: We web developers strive for rugged independence. The luckiest of us have total control over our web stacks and the design of our projects, unlike those poor sods forced to labor within the Content Management System (CMS). Therein lies the problem; being apart means being invisible unless you spread your content to the CMS and beyond. This panel will discuss some strategies and experiences for getting your app content to find readers where they are.
objects.title: Infect the CMS
objects.speaker: Jacob Harris, Al Shaw, Heather Billings

objects.title: Git & Github: Learning to commit to version control
objects.speaker: Tom Meagher

objects.title: Dodging disasters: How to avoid making errors with data
objects.speaker: Megan Luther, Liz Lucas, John Perry

objects.description: Labor unions may be struggling to maintain their membership, but they still play a pivotal role in the nation’s economy and politics. Tom and Mary Jo will discuss data you can use to dig into the public and private-sector unions in your region, shedding light on their finances, their membership and the ways they wield their considerable power.
objects.title: State of the Unions
objects.speaker: MaryJo Webster, Tom McGinty

objects.description: Wouldn't it be sweet if you got an email when something newsworthy happens? Wouldn't that make your job easier? Well, have we got news for you. Learn about implementing PANDA in your newsroom and automating your data chores.
objects.title: Make the robots work for you - implementing PANDA in your newsroom
objects.speaker: Brian Boyer, Christopher Groskopf, Nolan Hicks, David Eads

objects.title: Finding stories in health data
objects.speaker: David Donald, Charles Ornstein, Michael Pell

objects.title: Going beyond the obvious: Creative uses for data
objects.speaker: Ryann Grochowski, Terri Langford

objects.description: This three-part class is designed for data journalists who are comfortable with the basic tools of our craft but intimidated by the "p-word" and think Aron Pilhofer has signed a pact with the devil. We will cover the basics and show you how a little programming can save you hours or days of time and make you look like a genius to your boss. Requirements: a laptop, a Google sign-in and curiosity.
objects.title: Python programming for the rest of us 2: Basic Python

objects.description: Lots of people use Google Docs. But many of them don't know about the Google Apps Script language, which makes it possible to scrape data from across the web and from Google's geography, finance, machine learning and other APIs, then present and analyze the data in a Google Spreadsheet. This session will demonstrate the basics of Apps Script by building a spreadsheet that automatically imports new data from a public source every morning and sends an email when it comes across something interesting.
objects.title: Wrangling Web data with Google docs - advanced course
objects.speaker: Steven Melendez

objects.title: Mapping 2 with qGIS: Importing and selecting data by attribute
objects.speaker: David Herzog

objects.description: Stop by the IRE sales table and take a look at our merchandise. We will be selling books, including the newest title in the IRE beat book series. The large selection of titles we carry will certainly include your interests. The winners of the IRE T-shirt contest will be displayed and on sale. The sales table is also the place to get your ticket to "A Night on the Town" an event that is sure to be a fun time! All proceeds from your purchase help support IRE and its mission.
